The bacterial outer membrane enzyme PagP confers resistance to host immune defenses by transferring a palmitate chain from a phospholipid to the lipid A (endotoxin) component of lipopolysaccharide. PagP is an eight-stranded antiparallel β-barrel, preceded by an N-terminal amphipathic α-helix. The active site is localized inside the β-barrel and is aligned with the lipopolysaccharide-containing outer leaflet, but the phospholipid substrates are normally restricted to the inner leaflet of the asymmetric outer membrane. We examined the possibility that PagP activity in vivo depends on the aberrant migration of phospholipids into the outer leaflet. We find that brief addition to Escherichia coli cultures of millimolar EDTA, which is reported to replace a fraction of lipopolysaccharide with phospholipids, rapidly induces palmitoylation of lipid A. Although expression of the E. coli pagP gene is induced during Mg2+ limitation by the phoPQ two-component signal transduction pathway, EDTA-induced lipid A palmitoylation occurs more rapidly than pagP induction and is independent of de novo protein synthesis. EDTA-induced lipid A palmitoylation requires functional MsbA, an essential ATP-binding cassette transporter needed for lipid transport to the outer membrane. A potential role for the PagP α-helix in phospholipid translocation to the outer leaflet was excluded by showing that α-helix deletions are active in vivo. Neither EDTA nor Mg2+-EDTA stimulate PagP activity in vitro. These findings suggest that PagP remains dormant in outer membranes until Mg2+ limitation promotes the migration of phospholipids into the outer leaflet. Biological membranes are built from diverse lipids and proteins. Much information has been gained on the incorporation of proteins into membranes, but the trafficking of lipids during membrane biogenesis is poorly understood (for recent reviews see Refs. 1Huijbregts R.P. de Kroon A.I. de Kruijff B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1469: 43-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar and 2Kol M.A. de Kruijff B. de Kroon A.I. Semin. Cell Dev. Biol. 2002; 13: 163-170Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). Lipid biosynthesis is restricted primarily to the cytosolic leaflets of either the endoplasmic reticulum membrane in eukaryotic cells or the inner (cytoplasmic) membrane in bacteria. Membrane biogenesis thus depends on distinct lipid trafficking events including lateral diffusion, translocation between opposite leaflets (known also as flip-flop), and wholesale transport to distinct cellular compartments. Both lipid translocation and lipid transport are dependent on membrane proteins that may or may not utilize cellular energy (2Kol M.A. de Kruijff B. de Kroon A.I. Semin. Cell Dev. Biol. 2002; 13: 163-170Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). Lipid transport in eukaryotes proceeds through the budding and fusion of vesicles (3Nickel W. Brugger B. Wieland F.T. J. Cell Sci. 2002; 115: 3235-3240Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) or, less frequently, through sites of membrane contact (4Shiao Y.J. Lupo G. Vance J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 11190-11198Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar, 5Achleitner G. Gaigg B. Krasser A. Kainersdorfer E. Kohlwein S.D. Perktold A. Zellnig G. Daum G. Tuller G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1999; 264: 545-553Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). Although vesicles can bud off from bacterial outer membranes (6Beveridge T.J. J. Bacteriol. 1999; 181: 4725-4733Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Horstman A.L. Kuehn M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12489-12496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (313) Google Scholar), the peptidoglycan or murein layer is thought to prevent vesicle transport from bacterial cytoplasmic membranes. Possible roles for membrane contact sites or lipid transfer proteins in Gram-negative bacterial outer membrane biogenesis are subjects of current debate (1Huijbregts R.P. de Kroon A.I. de Kruijff B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1469: 43-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). Lipid trafficking during biogenesis of the bacterial outer membrane begins with the biosynthesis of phospholipids and lipopolysaccharide (LPS) 1The abbreviations used are: LPS, lipopolysaccharide; Kdo, 3-deoxy-d-manno-2-octulosonic acid; PBS, phosphate buffered saline. in the inner membrane (1Huijbregts R.P. de Kroon A.I. de Kruijff B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1469: 43-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar, 8Raetz C.R. Whitfield C. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2002; 71: 635-700Crossref PubMed Scopus (3381) Google Scholar). Passive translocation of phospholipids to the external leaflet of the inner membrane depends on the transmembrane α-helical segments of certain integral membrane proteins (9Kol M.A. van Dalen A. de Kroon A.I. de Kruijff B. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 24586-24593Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). An essential ATP-binding cassette transporter, or traffic-ATPase, MsbA is believed to translocate LPS across the inner membrane (10Zhou Z. White K.A. Polissi A. Georgopoulos C. Raetz C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 12466-12475Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar, 11Doerrler W.T. Reedy M.C. Raetz C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 11461-11464Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar, 12Chang G. Roth C.B. Science. 2001; 293: 1793-1800Crossref PubMed Scopus (585) Google Scholar, 13Doerrler W.T. Raetz C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 36697-36705Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar, 14Chang G. J. Mol. Biol. 2003; 330: 419-430Crossref PubMed Scopus (248) Google Scholar). The precise mechanism by which lipids are then transported to the outer membrane is unknown, but conditional mutants defective in MsbA have been shown recently to accumulate both phospholipids and LPS in the inner membrane (11Doerrler W.T. Reedy M.C. Raetz C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 11461-11464Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar). It has been known for over 25 years that phospholipids rapidly exchange between the inner and outer membranes, whereas the transport of LPS is unidirectional (15Jones N.C. Osborn M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1977; 252: 7405-7412Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Additionally, the organization of lipids in the outer membrane is highly asymmetric, with LPS located exclusively in the extracellular outer leaflet and phospholipids normally restricted to the periplasmic inner leaflet (16Kamio Y. Nikaido H. Biochemistry. 1976; 15: 2561-2570Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar). The asymmetric lipid organization of the outer membrane depends on the presence of divalent cations, particularly Mg2+ and Ca2+, which bridge negatively charged phosphate groups in the LPS (17Schindler M. Osborn M.J. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 4425-4430Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar, 18Coughlin R.T. Tonsager S. McGroarty E.J. Biochemistry. 1983; 22: 2002-2007Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). Removal of divalent cations with chelating agents such as EDTA can strip a fraction of LPS from the cell surface (19Leive L. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1974; 235: 109-129Crossref PubMed Scopus (349) Google Scholar). A large body of evidence indicates that EDTA promotes the translocation of phospholipids to the outer membrane outer leaflet (20Nikaido H. Microbiol. Mol. Biol. Rev. 2003; 67: 593-656Crossref PubMed Scopus (2867) Google Scholar, 21Nikaido H. Vaara M. Microbiol. Rev. 1985; 49: 1-32Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Consequently, phospholipids lost from the inner leaflet during EDTA treatment are likely replenished by lipid transport from the cytoplasmic membrane. PagP is an outer membrane enzyme that transfers a palmitate chain from the sn-1 position of a phospholipid to position 2 of the lipid A (endotoxin) component of LPS (22Bishop R.E. Gibbons H.S. Guina T. Trent M.S. Miller S.I. Raetz C.R. EMBO J. 2000; 19: 5071-5080Crossref PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar). Lipid A is built in the cytosolic leaflet of the inner membrane from a β-1′,6-linked disaccharide of glucosamine that is acylated with (R)-3-hydroxymyristate at the 2-, 3-, 2′-, and 3′-positions and is phosphorylated at the 1- and 4′-positions. Two units of 3-deoxy-d-manno-2-octulosonic acid (Kdo) are attached to the 6′-position, followed by the formation of acyloxyacyl linkages with laurate and myristate chains at the 2′- and 3′-positions, respectively (8Raetz C.R. Whitfield C. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2002; 71: 635-700Crossref PubMed Scopus (3381) Google Scholar). The resultant hexa-acylated Kdo2-lipid A or Re endotoxin (Fig. 1) is the simplest chemotype of LPS that can be transported to the outer membrane, although the structure is normally further glycosylated and phosphorylated to complete the core oligosaccharide before MsbA translocates the complex to the periplasmic leaflet of the inner membrane. The antigenic O-polysaccharide is usually attached in the periplasmic space to the distal sugar of the core oligosaccharide before transport to the outer membrane, but most laboratory strains of E. coli K12 do not synthesize the O-antigen. During infection, endotoxin is sensed by the immune system and can elicit a cascade of cytokine production that may lead to septic shock as a consequence of massive inflammation (23Aderem A. Ulevitch R.J. Nature. 2000; 406: 782-787Crossref PubMed Scopus (2623) Google Scholar). However, palmitoylated lipid A functions as an endotoxin antagonist in human cell lines by interfering with the toll-like receptor 4 inflammatory signaling pathway (24Tanamoto K. Azumi S. J. Immunol. 2000; 164: 3149-3156Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 25Kawasaki K. Ernst R.K. Miller S.I. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 20044-20048Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 26Muroi M. Ohnishi T. Tanamoto K. Infect. Immun. 2002; 70: 3546-3550Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar) and also provides bacterial resistance to vertebrate cationic antimicrobial peptides (27Guo L. Lim K.B. Poduje C.M. Daniel M. Gunn J.S. Hackett M. Miller S.I. Cell. 1998; 95: 189-198Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (522) Google Scholar). PagP promotes infections of the mammalian respiratory tract by providing bacterial resistance to host immune defenses (28Robey M. O'Connell W. Cianciotto N.P. Infect. The oligonucleotide primers used for DNA sequencing and PCR gene amplification were manufactured by Invitrogen and are described in Table III. Purification of plasmids, PCR products, and restriction fragments was performed with the QIAprep, QIAquick, and QIAEX II kits, respectively, according to the manufacturer's instructions (Qiagen). Genomic DNA was purified using the Easy-DNA kit (Invitrogen). DNA sequencing was performed at the ACGT Corp. sequencing facility (Toronto, Ontario, Canada). PCR gene amplification was performed with 2.5 units of Pfu polymerase in a volume of 50 μl of the supplied buffer with 100 ng of template DNA, 150 ng of the appropriate primers (Table III), and 10 μm dNTPs. After initial denaturation for 1 min at 94 °C, 30 cycles of 30 s at 94 °C, 1 min at the appropriate annealing temperature, and 2 min at 72 °C were performed and then followed by 10 min at 72 °C. Inverse PCR (43Xu Y. Gong Z. BioTechniques. 1999; 26: 639-641Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) was performed with 2.5 units of Pfu Turbo polymerase in a volume of 50 μl of the supplied buffer with 5 ng of pACPagP as template DNA, 200 ng of the appropriate primers phosphorylated at the 5′-ends (Table III), and 10 μm dNTPs. After initial denaturation for 5 min at 94 °C, 30 cycles of 1 min at 94 °C, 1 min at 60 °C, and 12 min at 72 °C were performed and then followed by 10 min at 72 °C. The PCR product was blunt end-ligated by using T4 DNA ligase. The Rtem β-lactamase gene from pUC19 was amplified by using the primers RTEM5NcoI and RTEM3SphI (Table III) at an annealing temperature of 50 °C, and cloned in the reverse orientation into the pagP gene of pCrcHB by NcoI/SphI digestion to create pPagAp. Replacement of the chromosomal pagP gene in E. coli MC1061 with the pagP::amp allele in pPagAp705 was performed by allelic exchange as described by Hamilton et al. (44Hamilton C.M. Aldea M. Washburn B.K. Babitzke P. Kushner S.R. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 4617-4622Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Allelic exchange was verified by PCR using genomic DNA template and the primers pagP1 and pagP2 (Table III) at an annealing temperature of 52 °C. The PCR product was sequenced using the same primers to verify the presence of the expected Rtem ligation junctions. The pagP gene under control of its endogenous promoter was amplified from pCrcHD, using the primers HD5HindIII and HD3BamHI (Table III) at an annealing temperature of 52 °C, and cloned into pACYC184 (Table II) by HindIII/BamHI digestion to create pACPagP. The pagP promoter was amplified from pCrcHB, using the primers HB5EcoRI and HB3BamHI (Table III) at an annealing temperature of 46 °C with 200 μm dNTPs, and cloned in pRS551 (Table II) by EcoRI/BamHI digestion to create pPagP551. Analysis of Lipid A by TLC—Analysis of lipid A released by mild acid hydrolysis from 32Pi-labeled cells was adapted from Zhou et al. (47Zhou Z. Lin S. Cotter R.J. Raetz C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 18503-18514Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar). An overnight culture grown at 37 °C was diluted 100-fold into 5 ml of LB broth containing appropriate antibiotics and 5 μCi/ml 32Pi and was allowed to grow at 37 °C for 3 h, unless indicated otherwise. The 32P-labeled cells were harvested by centrifugation and washed once with 5 ml of PBS. The pellet was resuspended in 0.8 ml of PBS and converted into a single-phase Bligh/Dyer mixture (48Bligh E.G. Dyer W.J. Can. J. Biochem. 1959; 37: 911-917Crossref PubMed Scopus (42875) Google Scholar) by adding 2 ml of methanol and 1 ml of chloroform. After 10 min of incubation at room temperature, the insoluble material was collected by centrifugation in a clinical centrifuge. The pellet was washed once with 5 ml of a fresh single-phase Bligh/Dyer mixture, consisting of chloroform/methanol/water (1:2:0.8, v/v). This pellet was then dispersed in 1.8 ml of 12.5 mm sodium acetate, pH 4.5, containing 1% SDS, with sonic irradiation in a bath apparatus. The mixture was incubated at 100 °C for 30 min to cleave the ketosidic linkage between Kdo and the distal glucosamine sugar of lipid A. After cooling, the boiled mixture was converted to a two-phase Bligh/Dyer mixture by adding 2 ml of chloroform and 2 ml of methanol. Partitioning was made by centrifugation, and the lower phase material was collected and washed once with 4 ml of the upper phase derived from a fresh neutral two-phase Bligh/Dyer mixture, consisting of chloroform/methanol/water (2:2:1.8, v/v). The lower phase lipid A sample was collected and dried under a stream of nitrogen gas. The lipid A sample was dissolved in 100 μl of chloroform/methanol (4:1, v/v), and an ∼1000 cpm portion of the sample was applied to the origin of a Silica Gel 60 TLC plate. TLC was conducted in a developing tank in the solvent of chloroform, pyridine, 88% formic acid, water (50:50:16:5, v/v). The plate was dried and visualized with a PhosphorImager (Amersham Biosciences). Lipid A was similarly analyzed in the culture medium, following treatment of the cells with or without EDTA, with some modifications from the above procedure. Ten μCi/ml 32Pi was added to 5 ml of LB, and the subcultured bacteria were allowed to grow for 130 min. The immunoregulatory cytokine interleukin 10 (IL-10) modulates the function of diverse immune and non-immune cells. Here, we examine the chromatin structural changes associated with IL10 gene transcription by naïve and differentiated murine T cells. Naïve T cells lack DNase I hypersensitive (HS) sites in the vicinity of the IL10 gene, whereas differentiated T cells display a strong 3′ constitutive HS site as well as several inducible sites. The majority of HS sites map to regions that are strongly conserved in sequence between mouse and human genomes. In committed Th1 cells, the mechanism of IL10 gene silencing is associated with the development of repressive histone modifications near the IL10 promoter and also near intronic hypersensitive regions of the IL10 gene. Our results constitute the first report of chromatin structural differences within the IL10 gene in differentiated Th1 and Th2 cells and emphasize the surprising diversity of mechanisms used to regulate cytokine gene expression at the chromatin level. The immunoregulatory cytokine interleukin 10 (IL-10) modulates the function of diverse immune and non-immune cells. Here, we examine the chromatin structural changes associated with IL10 gene transcription by naïve and differentiated murine T cells. Naïve T cells lack DNase I hypersensitive (HS) sites in the vicinity of the IL10 gene, whereas differentiated T cells display a strong 3′ constitutive HS site as well as several inducible sites. The majority of HS sites map to regions that are strongly conserved in sequence between mouse and human genomes. In committed Th1 cells, the mechanism of IL10 gene silencing is associated with the development of repressive histone modifications near the IL10 promoter and also near intronic hypersensitive regions of the IL10 gene. Our results constitute the first report of chromatin structural differences within the IL10 gene in differentiated Th1 and Th2 cells and emphasize the surprising diversity of mechanisms used to regulate cytokine gene expression at the chromatin level. IL-10 1The abbreviations used are: IL, interleukin; CNS, conserved noncoding sequence; CsA, cyclosporin A; ChIP, chromatin immunoprecipitation; HDAC, histone deacetylase; HS, hypersensitive; IFN, interferon; Th, T (cell) helper; MAPKAP2, mitogen-activated protein kinase activated protein 2; NFAT, nuclear factor of activated T cells; PMA, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate.1The abbreviations used are: IL, interleukin; CNS, conserved noncoding sequence; CsA, cyclosporin A; ChIP, chromatin immunoprecipitation; HDAC, histone deacetylase; HS, hypersensitive; IFN, interferon; Th, T (cell) helper; MAPKAP2, mitogen-activated protein kinase activated protein 2; NFAT, nuclear factor of activated T cells; PMA, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate. is an important regulatory cytokine with an overall immunosuppressive effect on the immune response. It is produced by many cell types, including T cells, B cells, monocytes, macrophages, and dendritic cells. IL-10 makes a positive contribution to the growth and differentiation of B cells, mast cells, granulocytes, dendritic cells, keratinocytes, and endothelial cells but inhibits a broad spectrum of the functions of activated macrophages and monocytes, including nitric oxide production, the expression of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins, and the expression of the costimulatory receptors CD80 and CD86 (see Ref. 1Moore K.W. de Waal Malefyt R. Coffman R.L. O'Garra A. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2001; 19: 683-765Crossref PubMed Scopus (5297) Google Scholar for a review). IL-10 inhibits NF-κB, a transcription factor involved in the production of inflammatory cytokines (e.g. IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, and tumor necrosis factor-α), while stimulating the production of cytokine inhibitors (e.g. the IL-1 receptor antagonist and the soluble tumor necrosis factor receptor) by monocytes/macrophages and neutrophils (2Salazar-Onfray F. Med. Oncol. 1999; 16: 86-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). IL-10-deficient mice develop severe chronic enterocolitis (inflammatory bowel disease), emphasizing the protective role of this cytokine in inflammatory and autoimmune conditions. Paradoxically, however, IL-10 stimulates polyclonal B cell activation and, thus, has a pathogenic role in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE); indeed, anti-IL-10 treatment ameliorates disease in a subset of human SLE patients. At least two types of T helper (Th) cells, Th1 and Th2, have been distinguished based on their cytokine expression profiles (see Ref. 3Fickenscher H. Hor S. Kupers H. Knappe A. Wittmann S. Sticht H. Trends Immunol. 2002; 23: 89-96Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar for a review). Both of these cells are derived from a common precursor, i.e. naïve CD4 T cells that have not yet encountered antigen. When naïve T cells are stimulated through their T cell receptors in the presence of IL-12 and interferon (IFN)-γ, they differentiate to produce IFN-γ but not IL-4 or IL-10; in contrast, when the same cells are stimulated in the presence of IL-4, they differentiate to show the converse pattern of cytokine production, producing IL-4 and IL-10 but not IFN-γ. These mutually exclusive patterns of cytokine production are predominantly observed in fully committed Th1 and Th2 cells that have been exposed to differentiating stimuli ex vivo under conditions where differentiation can be driven by high concentrations of T cell antigen receptor stimulation and polarizing cytokines. T cell clones made from these polarized cell populations are ideal for biochemical studies of gene expression, because they can be maintained by culture in the presence of the growth factor IL-2. In particular, Th1 and Th2 clones have been very useful in demonstrating that the IL4 and IFNγ genes bear opposing chromatin modifications depending on the direction of polarization (4Avni O. Lee D. Macian F. Szabo S.J. Glimcher L.H. Rao A. Nat. Immunol. 2002; 3: 643-651Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 5Agarwal S. Rao A. Immunity. 1998; 9: 765-775Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (613) Google Scholar). Th1 cells develop a strongly silenced chromatin configuration on the IL4 gene but display an “open” chromatin configuration characterized by increased DNase I hypersensitivity and histone acetylation on the IFNγ gene; similarly, Th2 cells develop an active chromatin configuration and a complex pattern of DNase I hypersensitivity on the IL4 gene, while at the same time silencing the IFNγ gene (6Ansel K.M. Lee D.U. Rao A. Nat. Immunol. 2003; 4: 616-623Crossref PubMed Scopus (365) Google Scholar). The expanded IL-10 family includes several viral members as well as the IL-10-related cytokines IL-19, IL-20, IL-22 (IL-TIF), IL-24 (MDA-7), and IL-26 (AK155). By sequence alignment, these cytokines display up to ∼30% amino acid sequence identity to IL-10 (up to ∼80% for the viral homologues) (3Fickenscher H. Hor S. Kupers H. Knappe A. Wittmann S. Sticht H. Trends Immunol. 2002; 23: 89-96Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar). Based on the strong similarity between their crystal structures, IL-10 belongs to the same cytokine family as IFN-γ (7Zdanov A. Schalk-Hihi C. Gustchina A. Tsang M. Weatherbee J. Wlodawer A. Structure. 1995; 3: 591-601Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar), and the genes for the IL-10/IFN-γ family are clustered on two chromosomes, emphasizing their relatively recent divergence during evolution. The genes encoding IL-22 and IL-26 are located in the close vicinity of the IFNγ gene on chromosome 12q15, whereas the genes for IL-10, IL-19, IL-20, and IL-24 are located in a second cluster flanked by the mitogen-activated protein kinase activated protein 2 (MAPKAP2) and TOSO (a regulator of Fas-induced apoptosis) genes; this cluster spans an ∼195-kb region of human chromosome 1q31– 32, which is syntenic to mouse chromosome 1E4 (Fig. 1). Although the immunoregulatory role of IL-10 has been extensively studied for decades, little information is available on the molecular mechanism of its transcriptional regulation, especially at the chromatin level. As a first approach to this question, we have examined the pattern of DNase I hypersensitivity in and around the IL10 gene in naïve and differentiated T cells. We show that whereas naïve T cells show no DNase I hypersensitive (HS) sites in the vicinity of the IL10 gene, differentiated T cells display a strong 3′ constitutive HS site as well as several inducible sites. Essentially, all of the HS sites correspond to conserved non-coding sequence (CNS) regions identified by sequence comparisons of mammalian genomes; but the pattern of inducible HS sites differs in Th1 and Th2 cells, which silence and express the IL10 gene, respectively. Committed Th1 cells develop repressive histone modifications at the IL10 promoter and at intronic hypersensitive regions of the IL10 gene, whereas committed Th2 cells develop an open chromatin configuration at the IL10 promoter and do not display the intronic hypersensitive sites. These data constitute the first report of chromatin structural changes that correlate with IL10 gene transcription. Immunol. 2002; 3: 643-651Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 19Agarwal S. Avni O. Rao A. Immunity. 2000; 12: 643-652Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). Analysis of DNase I Hypersensitivity and DNA Methylation—Cells were stimulated for 4 h as described above, and nuclei were isolated and incubated with DNase I (22Siebenlist U. Durand D.B. Bressler P. Holbrook N.J. Norris C.A. Kamoun M. Kant J.A. Crabtree G.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1986; 6: 3042-3049Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). Purified genomic DNAs were completely digested with BamHI and resolved on a 0.6% agarose gel, transferred to Nytran membranes, and hybridized with IL-10 exon 1, exon 3, or exon 5 probes labeled by random priming. For methylation analysis of Th1 (D5) and Th2 (D10) clones, genomic DNAs were prepared and digested completely with BamHI. The DNAs were purified and further digested with methylation-sensitive (HpaII; 100 units) or -insensitive (MspI) enzymes. Digested samples were further processed for Southern analysis with indicated IL-10 exon probes. Chromatin Immunoprecipitation (ChIP) Assays—ChIP analysis was carried out essentially as described (23Shang Y. Hu X. DiRenzo J. Lazar M.A. Brown M. Cell. 2000; 103: 843-852Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1445) Google Scholar). Th1 (D5) or Th2 (D10) cells (108) were either left unstimulated or stimulated for 20 min with PMA (10 nm) plus ionomycin (2 μm) and then cross-linked using formaldehyde. This early time point was chosen based on the early kinetics of IL-10 gene transcription (peak transcript levels attained at 20 min in both the D10 Th2 clone and primary Th2 cells; Fig. 2 and data not shown). Nuclei were isolated and sonicated four times for 10 s each at the maximal setting with 1 min of cooling on ice in between. The average size of sonicated DNA was ∼0.5kb. The chromatin was immunoprecipitated using anti-NFAT1 (anti-67.1 and anti-NFAT1-C antibodies specific for the family member NFAT1-C) (24Wang D. McCaffrey P. Rao A. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1995; 766: 182-194Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar), anti-acetyl-histone H4 (Upstate Biotechnology, Lake Placid, NY), anti-Pol II (sc-899; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA), or rabbit IgG (Sigma). Following the reversal of cross-links, the presence of selected DNA sequences was assessed by PCR. The primers used in ChIP were as follows: IL-10 promoter, 5′-GAGTGCTAAGGTGACTTCCGA-3′ and 5′-AACTTCTGCATTACAGCTATTTTT-3′ (280-bp product); IL-4 promoter, 5′-TGATAAGATTAGTCTGAAAGGCCGATT-3′ and 5′-GTTTATCAAGAGATGCTAACAATGCAATG-3′ (300-bp product); and IFN-γ promoter, 5′-CTGTGCTCTGTGGATGAGAAATTCACA-3′ and 5′-TTTAAGATGGTGACAGATAGGTGGG-3′ (257-bp product). As a loading control, the PCR was done directly on input DNA purified from chromatin before immunoprecipitation. PCR products were resolved on 1.5% agarose gels. Bioinformatics—Alignments between the mouse and human IL-10 loci were performed, and the extent of DNA sequence homology was computed with a web-based program called VISTA (www.gsd.lbl.gov/vista) (12Mayor C. Brudno M. Schwartz J.R. Poliakov A. Rubin E.M. Frazer K.A. Pachter L.S. Dubchak I. Bioinformatics. 2000; 16: 1046-1047Crossref PubMed Scopus (791) Google Scholar, 13Dubchak I. Brudno M. Loots G.G. Pachter L. Mayor C. Rubin E.M. Frazer K.A. Genome Res. 2000; 10: 1304-1306Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar). In Fig. 6, the plot of the percentage of sequence identity is referred to the mouse sequence. Regions with a length of at least 100 bp, which show at least 75% sequence identity at each segment of the alignment between successive gaps, are identified as CNS regions and are shown in red in Fig. 6. The IL10 Cytokine Cluster—Fig. 1 shows the organization of the IL10/IL19/IL20/IL24 cytokine cluster on human chromosome 1q31–32, syntenic to mouse chromosome 1E4. The IL10 gene is located 35 kb from the MAPKAP2 gene in the human (25 kb in the mouse) and 62 kb from the IL19 gene (89 kb in the mouse). In this study we focus on a 22-kb region surrounding the IL10 gene contained within two BamH I fragments of 6 and 16 kb (Fig. 1). Differential DNase I Hypersensitivity of the IL10 Gene in Th1 and Th2 Cells—We compared the chromatin structure of the IL10 gene in Th1 and Th2 cells using two fully differentiated T cell clones, D5 and D10 (8Rao A. Faas S.J. Cantor H. J. Exp. Med. 1984; 159: 479-494Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 9Kaye J. Porcelli S. Tite J. Jones B. Janeway C.A.J. J. Exp. Med. 1983; 158: 836-856Crossref PubMed Scopus (557) Google Scholar). D5 cells, which belong to the Th1 subtype, have silenced the IL10 gene and show no expression of IL10 mRNA regardless of whether or not they are stimulated. In contrast, D10 cells, which belong to the Th2 subtype, basally express low levels of IL10 transcripts under resting conditions and rapidly induce IL10 mRNA and protein upon stimulation with either PMA and ionomycin or anti-CD3 (Ref. 5Agarwal S. Rao A. Immunity. 1998; 9: 765-775Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (613) Google Scholar and data not shown). We used an exon 1 probe to examine the DNase I hypersensitivity pattern in the 5′-region of the IL10 gene in these two cell types (Fig. 2A). Consistent with their basal expression of the IL10 gene, resting D10 cells showed a strong HS site at the proximal IL10 promoter; this site was not apparent in resting D5 cells, which have silenced IL-10 gene expression (Fig. 2A). We next repeated the experiment using primary Th1 and Th2 cells, which do not express or express high levels of IL10 mRNA and protein respectively (Ref. 5Agarwal S. Rao A. Immunity. 1998; 9: 765-775Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (613) Google Scholar and data not shown). Again, primary Th1 cells showed no evidence of DNase I hypersensitivity at the IL10 promoter, whereas Th2 cells showed an obvious HS site (Fig. 2B). We used probes spanning exon 3 and exon 5 to monitor DNase I hypersensitivity patterns in the 16-kb BamHI fragment containing the 3′-region of the IL10 gene (Fig. 3). Using the exon 3 probe and resting D5 T cells, we showed that these cells displayed a strong constitutive HS site (designated HS site III) located ∼5.5 kb from the intronic BamHI site (Fig. 3, A and E, black arrows). Stimulation resulted in the appearance of strong inducible bands of 1 and 2.5 kb, corresponding to cleavage at inducible HS sites I and II (Fig. 3, A and E, gray arrows). These bands were weakly induced by ionomycin stimulation alone (Fig. 3A, lanes 7–12), substantially more strongly induced upon stimulation with both PMA and ionomycin (lanes 13–18), and lost upon stimulation in the presence of CsA (lanes 19–23). In addition, we also observed weak inducible bands of ∼7 and ∼8 kb corresponding to HS sites IV and V (Fig. 3, A and E, gray arrows). A very similar pattern was observed when the same blot was rehybridized with the exon 5 probe (data not shown). A diagram interpreting these hypersensitivity patterns is shown in Fig. 3E. We repeated the DNase I hypersensitivity analysis using the D10 Th2 clone (Fig. 3B). Although resting D10 cells displayed the constitutive HS site located ∼5.5 kb from the intronic BamHI site (Fig. 3B), they showed a far more limited pattern of inducible HS sites. Specifically, these cells did not show the inducible bands of 1 and 2.5 kb corresponding to cleavage at inducible HS sites I and II, although they did display the inducible bands of ∼7 and ∼8 kb resulting from cleavage at HS sites IV and V (Fig. 3, B and E). We confirmed the observation that primary T cells displayed a similar pattern of HS sites (Fig. 3, C and D). Naïve precursor CD4 T cells showed no evidence of any HS sites on the IL10 gene, using either the exon 5 or the exon 1 probe (data not shown). However the patterns of DNase I hypersensitivity observed in primary differentiated Th1 and Th2 cells were similar to those observed in D5 and D10 clones, respectively. Specifically, primary Th1 cells exhibited the intronic HS sites, whereas primary Th2 cells did not (Fig. 3, C and D). Together, these data show that Th1 and Th2 cells differ in their patterns of DNase I hypersensitivity on the IL10 gene. Curiously, Th1 cells, which do not express the IL10 gene, show a more complex pattern of HS sites in the vicinity of the IL10 gene than do Th2 cells, which strongly express the gene. Silencing of the IL10 Promoter in the D5 Th1 Clone—The presence of a constitutive HS site at the IL10 promoter region in D10/Th2 but not D5/Th1 cells (Fig. 2), taken together with the ability of D10/Th2 but not D5/Th1 cells to transcribe IL10 (5Agarwal S. Rao A. Immunity. 1998; 9: 765-775Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (613) Google Scholar), suggested that the promoter was poised for active transcription in Th2 cells but silenced in committed Th1 cells. To test this hypothesis, we used the ChIP technique (Fig. 4A). For technical reasons, only D5 and D10 clones, which constitute homogeneous, committed, and strongly transcribing cell populations, could be used in this assay. The cells were stimulated and fixed with formaldehyde to cross-link DNA-protein complexes, and sheared DNAs were immunoprecipitated using antibodies to RNA polymerase II, acetylated histone H4, and the inducible transcription factor NFAT1. PCR was performed to detect association of the IL10 promoter with the respective immunoprecipitated fraction; IL4 and IFNγ promoter primers were used as controls. Like the IL4 promoter, the IL10 promoter was hyperacetylated on histone H4 in D10 Th2 cells even prior to stimulation (Fig. 4A, top two panels, rows labeled anti-acetylH4). Both promoters showed basal occupancy by RNA polymerase II (Pol II) (Fig. 4A, top two panels, rows labeled anti-Pol II), confirming their poised status. IL4 and IL10 promoters became accessible to NFAT1 after stimulation (Fig. 4A, top two panels, rows labeled anti-NFAT1), correlating with the rapid increase in IL-4 and IL-10 production by stimulated D10 cells. In contrast, D5 T cells, which do not produce either IL-4 or IL-10, showed no histone hyperacetylation, Pol II occupancy, or inducible NFAT1 binding at either of these two promoters (Fig. 4A, top two panels). However these cells showed constitutive hyperacetylation, constitutive Pol II occupancy, and inducible NFAT1 binding at the IFNγ promoter, consistent with their competence to produce IFN-γ upon stimulation (Fig. 4A, bottom panel). As a further test of differential promoter accessibility, we probed the methylation status of the IL10 promoter in D5 and D10 cells using the methylation-sensitive and -insensitive enzyme pair HpaII/MspI, which recognizes 5′-CCGG sites (Fig. 4B). BamHI digestion of D5 or D10 DNA yielded a 6-kb band that hybridized to the exon 1 probe (Fig. 4B, lanes 1 and 3), whereas digestion with BamHI plus MspI yielded the expected 1.2- and 0.7-kb fragments hybridizing to the exon 1 probe (Fig. 4B, lanes 2 and 4; see diagram at bottom). After HpaII digestion of D5 DNA, the 6-kb fragment was partially converted to a slightly smaller fragment with no appearance of a 0.7-kb fragment (Fig. 4B, lane 3), indicating partial demethylation of the intronic HpaII site (c) but complete methylation of the HpaII sites in the IL10 promoter (a) and in exon 1 (b) (see diagram in Fig. 4B). In contrast, BamHI-digested D10 DNA was fully cleaved by HpaII, resulting in 1.2- and 0.7-kb fragments hybridizing to the IL10 exon 1 probe (Fig. 4B, lane 6) and showing full demethylation at all three HpaII sites. NFAT Binding to an Intronic Region of the IL10 Gene in the D5 Th1 Clone—Given the degree of promoter inactivation in D5 cells, it was surprising that inducible HS sites appeared in intronic regions of the IL10 gene in Th1 cells stimulated with PMA and ionomycin (Figs. 3 and 4). We examined whether histones at HS sites I and II bore two modifications generally associated with active genes, i.e. acetylation of histone H4 and dimethylation of histone 3 and lysine 4 (10Rice J.C. Allis C.D. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2001; 13: 263-273Crossref PubMed Scopus (562) Google Scholar, 11Jenuwein T. Allis C.D. Science. 2001; 293: 1074-1080Crossref PubMed Scopus (7632) Google Scholar). As expected from the silenced status of the IL10 gene in D5 cells, the levels of both histone modifications were considerably lower in D5 cells than in D10 cells (Fig. 5A, top two rows). Furthermore, the histone deacetylase HDAC1 was more strongly associated with HS sites I and II in D5 cells than in D10 cells (third row from top), which is again consistent with IL10 gene silencing in D5 cells. Because CsA blocked induction of all the inducible HS sites in D5 Th1 cells (Figs. 3 and 4), we asked whether NFAT proteins participated in their formation. We searched for conserved NFAT binding sites in the IL10 promoter and intronic regions using the program rVISTA (version 2.0; rvista.dcode.org/) (12Mayor C. Brudno M. Schwartz J.R. Poliakov A. Rubin E.M. Frazer K.A. Pachter L.S. Dubchak I. Bioinformatics. 2000; 16: 1046-1047Crossref PubMed Scopus (791) Google Scholar, 13Dubchak I. Brudno M. Loots G.G. Pachter L. Mayor C. Rubin E.M. Frazer K.A. Genome Res. 2000; 10: 1304-1306Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar). This analysis identified NFAT binding sites in the IL10 promoter, intron 3 and intron 4, which were strongly conserved between human and mouse (Fig. 5B and data not shown). ChIP assays showed that NFAT1 bound strongly and inducibly to the inducible HS site II, located in intron 4 of the IL10 gene, in D5 but not in D10 cells (Fig. 5A, fourth row from the top). In contrast, NFAT1 did not bind to HS site I located in intron 3, even though this intron contains a conserved NFAT binding site. The difference could reflect the different sequence contexts of the NFAT binding sites; the sites at the promoter and intron 4 do not contain an adjacent AP-1 binding site (Fig. 5B), and NFAT binding may therefore be stabilized by a partner protein already present in the nucleus under the stimulation conditions used, whereas the site in intron 3 is likely a composite NFAT:AP-1 site in the mouse (data not shown), which would be predicted not to support NFAT binding at early times after stimulation when AP-1 proteins are not yet induced (14Jain J. Miner Z. Rao A. J. Immunol. 1993; 151: 837-848PubMed Google Scholar). We have defined the patterns of DNase I hypersensitivity in the IL10 locus of naïve and differentiating T cells. DNase I hypersensitive sites mark nucleosome-poor regions that tend to be located in the vicinity of protein-bound regulatory elements; these regions have been shown in different systems to function as enhancers, locus control regions, matrix attachment regions, or insulator/boundary elements. DNase I hypersensitivity analysis is useful for at least two reasons, i.e. it provides a first indication of whether a gene is transcriptionally competent or silenced, and it constitutes a simple method for long-range mapping of potentially important regulatory regions of the gene. Bioinformatic analysis of the IL10 gene shows a remarkable correspondence between the positions of experimentally determined HS regions and the CNS regions identified by sequence comparisons of mammalian genomes (Fig. 6). This correspondence appears to be a common feature of cytokine genes, because it has also been noted in the IL4/IL13 and IFNγ loci (6Ansel K.M. Lee D.U. Rao A. Nat. Immunol. 2003; 4: 616-623Crossref PubMed Scopus (365) Google Scholar, 15Loots G.G. Locksley R.M. Blankespoor C.M. Wang Z.E. Miller W. Rubin E.M. Frazer K.A. Science. 2000; 288: 136-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (661) Google Scholar, 16Takemoto N. Koyano-Nakagawa N. Yokota T. Arai N. Miyatake S. Arai K. Int. Immunol. 1998; 10: 1981-1985Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar, 17Lee D.U. Avni O. Chen L. Rao A. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4802-4810Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). 2J. Nardone, D. Lee, M. Ansel, and A. Rao, unpublished observations. All six HS sites identified in our analysis, HS sites I–V and the HS site at the IL10 promoter, map in the vicinity of CNS regions that are highly conserved between human and mouse (Fig. 6; note that HS sites are generally found at the boundaries of protein-bound regulatory elements and not within the occupied regions themselves) (18Hernandez-Munain C. Roberts J.L. Krangel M.S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 3223-3233Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). A longer-range view of the IL10 locus, shown in Fig. 6B, indicates the presence of several other CNS regions in the vicinity of the IL10 gene. Further analysis is needed to determine which of these regions is pertinent to regulation of the IL10 gene and which is pertinent to regulation of the flanking IL19 and MAPKAP2 genes. A comprehensive analysis of DNase I hypersensitivity, performed in a large number of different IL-10-producing cell types at all possible developmental stages and under all possible conditions of stimulation, will be necessary to reveal all of the conserved regions that participate in IL10 regulation in any given cell type under specified conditions of stimulation. The most striking hypersensitive site in the IL10 locus is constitutive HS site III, located immediately 3′ of the last exon of the IL10 gene. This site is not apparent in naïve CD4 T cells and develops in both Th1 and Th2 cells following T cell antigen receptor stimulation. The sequence of HS III is highly conserved (∼85%) in human, mouse, and rats (data not shown) and corresponds to a CNS region as shown in Fig. 6. The characteristic properties of this site (absence from naïve T cells and having constitutive rather than inducible hypersensitivity in differentiated T cells) suggest that it binds lineage-specific transcription factors rather than inducible transcription factors that mediate acute transcription of the IL10 gene. Like GATA3 and T-bet in Th1 and Th2 cells, respectively, such lineage-specific factor(s) responsible for IL10 gene expression may function to impose the remodeled chromatin structure of the IL10 locus and maintain it in a transcriptionally competent state (6Ansel K.M. Lee D.U. Rao A. Nat. Immunol. 2003; 4: 616-623Crossref PubMed Scopus (365) Google Scholar). Our studies focus attention on the IL10 promoter as a major region that determines IL10 expression in differentiated T cells. The promoter is the only identified region of the IL10 gene that assumes a fully inactive chromatin configuration in committed D5 Th1 cells as judged by hypoacetylation at histone H4, CpG methylation at two HpaII sites, and inaccessibility to binding of the inducible transcription factor NFAT1. The remainder of the IL10 locus remains accessible to binding of transcription factors as judged by the appearance of intronic and 3′ inducible hypersensitive sites and the direct demonstration of NFAT1 binding to HS site II by ChIP. This behavior is quite different from that documented previously for IL4, where Th1 cells that have shut off IL4 not only silence the IL4 promoter (Fig. 4) (4Avni O. Lee D. Macian F. Szabo S.J. Glimcher L.H. Rao A. Nat. Immunol. 2002; 3: 643-651Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) but show no HS sites other than those observed in naïve T cells (5Agarwal S. Rao A. Immunity. 1998; 9: 765-775Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (613) Google Scholar) and do not develop the inducible HS site at the 3′ IL4 enhancer following stimulation (19Agarwal S. Avni O. Rao A. Immunity. 2000; 12: 643-652Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). The promoter-directed silencing of the IL10 gene also contrasts with the behavior of the IFNγ gene, which, when silenced in Th2 cells, shows no hypersensitivity whatsoever (19Agarwal S. Avni O. Rao A. Immunity. 2000; 12: 643-652Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). It is curious that the binding of NFAT1 to several cytokine promoters (IL10, IL4, and IFNγ) correlates with an open configuration of chromatin, characterized for instance by increased levels of histone H4 acetylation prior to stimulation (4Avni O. Lee D. Macian F. Szabo S.J. Glimcher L.H. Rao A. Nat. Immunol. 2002; 3: 643-651Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), whereas binding of the same transcription factor to intron 4 (HS site II) of the IL10 gene occurs despite a “silenced” chromatin configuration characterized by decreased histone H4 acetylation, decreased histone H3K4 dimethylation, and constitutive association with the histone deacetylase HDAC1. Inducible binding of NFAT1 to a site in exon 1 of the cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) gene was reported to repress CDK4 expression by recruiting HDAC1 (20Baksh S. Widlund H.R. Frazer-Abel A.A. Du J. Fosmire S. Fisher D.E. DeCaprio J.A. Modiano J.F. Burakoff S.J. Mol. Cell. 2002; 10: 1071-1081Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). HDAC recruitment by NFAT may also contribute to silencing of a subset of the large number of genes, identified by DNA array analyses, whose expression is decreased by calcium/calcineurin signaling (21Feske S. Giltnane J. Dolmetsch R. Staudt L.M. Rao A. Nat. Immunol. 2001; 2: 316-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (498) Google Scholar). However, in the IL10 gene HDAC1 is constitutively associated with both IL10 introns in D5 cells, whereas NFAT1 binds inducibly only to intron 4, suggesting that HDAC1 is recruited not by NFAT but rather by repressive factor(s) pre-bound to the intronic HS sites. The identity of these repressive factors awaits further analysis. To summarize, our data emphasize the surprising diversity of mechanisms used to regulate gene expression at the chromatin level. We have defined for the first time the DNase I hypersensitivity patterns of the IL10 gene in naïve and differentiated T cells. This analysis has revealed that the majority of DNase I hypersensitive sites correspond to conserved non-coding genomic regions that were identified by sequence comparisons of mammalian genomes. Furthermore, the analysis shows that different cell types expressing the same gene choose different subsets of the conserved CNS regions as DNase I hypersensitive sites, implying that the evolutionary conservation of these regions derives not from their simultaneous participation in gene expression in all expressing cell types but rather from their specialized roles as protein binding regulatory elements in individual cell types. We have also described a novel silencing mechanism directed selectively to the promoter of the IL10 gene, which is not observed in other cytokine genes such as IL4 and IFNγ. Because this mechanism appears to maintain IL10 intronic regions in a state of reversible HDAC-mediated silencing even in fully committed T cell clones, it may represent an evolutionary adaptation that permits reactivation of the IL10 gene under appropriate physiological or pathological conditions. We thank Fernando Cruz-Guilloty for assistance with aspects of the project, Suneet Agarwal for the Southern blots used in Figs. 2B and 3, Mark Ansel for help with the VISTA analysis, and members of the Rao laboratory for valuable discussions.

We have recently reported that two typical Gs-coupled receptors, the β2-adrenergic receptor and the receptor for prostaglandin E1, stimulate phospholipase C-ϵ (PLC-ϵ) and increase intracellular Ca2+ concentration ([Ca2+]i) in HEK-293 cells and N1E-115 neuroblastoma cells, respectively, by a pathway involving Epac1, a cAMP-activated and Rap-specific guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF), and the GTPase Rap2B. Here we have demonstrated that these Gs-coupled receptors use this pathway to activate H-Ras and the extracellular signal-regulated kinases 1 and 2 (ERK1/2). Specifically, agonist activation of the receptors resulted in activation of H-Ras and ERK1/2. The latter action was suppressed by dominant negative H-Ras, but not Rap1A. The receptor actions were independent of protein kinase A but fully mimicked by an Epac-specific cAMP analog as well as by a constitutively active Rap2B mutant. On the other hand, a cAMP-binding-deficient Epac1 mutant, the Rap GTPase-activating proteinII, and a dominant negative Rap2B mutant suppressed receptor- and Epac-mediated activation of H-Ras and ERK1/2. Finally, we have demonstrated that activation of H-Ras and ERK1/2 requires the lipase activity of PLC-ϵ and the subsequent [Ca2+]i increase, suggesting that H-Ras activation is mediated by a Ca2+-activated GEF. In line with this hypothesis, receptor-mediated activation of H-Ras and ERK1/2 was strongly enhanced by expression of RasGRP1, a Ca2+-regulated Ras-GEF. Collectively, our data indicated that Gs-coupled receptors can activate H-Ras and subsequently the mitogen-activated protein kinases ERK1/2 by a Ca2+-activated Ras-GEF, possibly RasGRP1, mediated by cAMP-activated Epac proteins, which then lead via Rap2B and PLC-ϵ stimulation to [Ca2+]i increase. In line with this hypothesis, receptor-mediated activation of H-Ras and ERK1/2 was strongly enhanced by expression of RasGRP1, a Ca2+-regulated Ras-GEF. Activation of mitogen-activated protein (MAP) 1The abbreviations used are: MAP, mitogen-activated protein; ERK, extracellular signal-regulated kinase; PKA, protein kinase A; β2-AR, β2-adrenergic receptor; PTX, pertussis toxin; GEF, guanine nucleotide exchange factor; PLC, phospholipase C; PGE1, prostaglandin E1; [Ca2+]i, intracellular Ca2+ concentration; 8-pCPT-2Me-cAMP, 8-(4-chlorophenylthio)-2′-O-methyl cyclic AMP; P-ERK1/2, phospho-ERK1/2; β-ARK-CT, carboxyl terminus of β-adrenergic receptor kinase; RapGAPII, Rap GTPase-activating proteinII; DAG, diacylglycerol. kinases plays a prominent role in many cellular responses to a large variety of membrane receptors. Initially identified as signal transducers of growth factor receptors with intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, activation of MAP kinases, specifically of the extracellular signal-regulated kinases 1 and 2 (ERK1/2), is now also recognized as a major signal transduction pathway of many receptors coupled to heterotrimeric G proteins. ERK activation by these second messenger-generating receptors is apparently accomplished by diverse molecular mechanisms, depending on the cell types studied as well as the receptor and the heterotrimeric G protein involved (1Pearson G. Robinson F. Gibson T.B. Xu B.-E. Karandikar M. Berman K. Cobb M.H. Endocr. Rev. 2001; 22: 153-183Crossref PubMed Scopus (3564) Google Scholar, 2Gutkind J.S. Science's STKE. 2000; (http://www.stke.org/cgi/content/full/OC_sigtrans;2000/40/re1)PubMed Google Scholar, 3Marinissen M.J. Gutkind J.S. Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 2001; 22: 368-376Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (844) Google Scholar, 4Pierce K.L. Luttrell L.M. Lefkowitz R.J. Oncogene. 2001; 20: 1532-1539Crossref PubMed Scopus (366) Google Scholar, 5Liebmann C. Cell. Signal. 2001; 13: 777-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar). The cAMP-producing Gs-coupled receptors play a rather unique role in ERK activation. These receptors inhibit ERK activation by growth factor receptors in several cell types while stimulating this cellular response in others, most notably in neuronal and endocrine cells. Several models have been proposed to explain these diverse actions of cAMP and Gs-coupled receptors on ERK activation, both apparently involving in most cases the principal cAMP target, the cAMP-activated protein kinase (PKA) (6Richards J.S. Mol. Endocrinol. 2001; 15: 209-218Crossref PubMed Scopus (342) Google Scholar, 7Stork P.J.S. Schmitt J.M. Trends Cell Biol. 2002; 12: 258-266Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (755) Google Scholar). In particular, PKA-dependent ERK activation in HEK-293 cells by the β2-adrenergic receptor (β2-AR), a prototypical Gs-coupled receptor, has been extensively studied. Lefkowitz and coworkers (8Daaka Y. Luttrell L.M. Lefkowitz R.J. Nature. 1997; 390: 88-91Crossref PubMed Scopus (1077) Google Scholar) reported that cAMP-activated PKA phosphorylates the β2-AR and thereby alters the coupling specificity of the receptor from Gs to Gi proteins. By this G protein “switching,” the β2-AR then apparently induces ERK activation by releasing Gβγ dimers from the pertussis toxin (PTX)-sensitive Gi proteins, followed by activation of the cytosolic tyrosine kinase c-Src, the GTPase Ras, and the MAP kinase kinase kinase, Raf-1. Meanwhile, it has been reported that the switching of β2-AR from Gs to Gi proteins is controlled by β-arrestin, which recruits the cAMP-degrading phosphodiesterase 4 to the plasma membrane and thereby alters the activity state of PKA (9Baillie G.S. Sood A. McPhee I. Gall I. Perry S.J. Lefkowitz R.J. Houslay M.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 940-945Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar). In contrast, Schmitt and Stork (10Schmitt J.M. Stork P.J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25342-25350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar) report that ERK activation by the β2-AR in HEK-293 cells, although also PKA- and c-Src-dependent, is PTX-insensitive and thus apparently does not require β2-AR switching to Gi proteins, a finding recently confirmed by others using a PKA-insensitive β2-AR mutant (11Friedmann J. Babu B. Clark R.B. Mol. Pharmacol. 2002; 62: 1094-1102Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Furthermore, Schmitt and Stork (10Schmitt J.M. Stork P.J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25342-25350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar) show that ERK activation by β2-AR is not mediated by Ras but by the related GTPase Rap1, activating the MAP kinase kinase kinase B-Raf, but not Raf-1. Interestingly, activation of the β2-AR also resulted in Ras activation, but this receptor action was apparently independent of cAMP and PKA (10Schmitt J.M. Stork P.J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25342-25350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar). Recently, these authors reported that activation of Rap1 by the β2-AR is apparently mediated by direct phosphorylation of c-Src on serine 17 by PKA, whereas activation of Ras by the β2-AR involves Gβγ dimers and c-Src and finally leads to phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase-dependent activation of AKT (12Schmitt J.M. Stork P.J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 43024-43032Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Activation of Rap1 by PKA-phosphorylated c-Src obviously also accounts for the inhibition of Ras/Raf-1/ERK signaling by Rap1 by sequestering Raf-1 to specific membrane domains and thereby preventing Raf-1 activation by Ras (13Schmitt J.M. Stork P.J.S. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 85-94Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar, 14Carey K.D. Watson R.T. Pessin J.E. Stork P.J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 3185-3196Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). Few reports indicate that cAMP-dependent ERK activation by Gs-coupled receptors can also occur independently of PKA, such as the thyrotropin-induced ERK activation in FRTL5 cells (15Iacovelli L. Capobianco L. Salvatore L. Sallese M. D'Ancona G.M. De Blasi A. Mol. Pharmacol. 2001; 60: 924-933Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar) and the parathyroid hormone-induced ERK activation in bone cells (16Fujita T. Meguro T. Fukuyama R. Nakamuta H. Koida M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 22191-22200Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). Both receptor actions apparently involve Rap1 and B-Raf (15Iacovelli L. Capobianco L. Salvatore L. Sallese M. D'Ancona G.M. De Blasi A. Mol. Pharmacol. 2001; 60: 924-933Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 16Fujita T. Meguro T. Fukuyama R. Nakamuta H. Koida M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 22191-22200Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). Similar data were recently reported for calcitonin-induced ERK activation in native rat kidney cells (17Larouche-Joubert N. Marsy S. Michelet S. Imbert-Teboul M. Doucet A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 18598-18604Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). Using a specific antibody, evidence was provided that the PKA-independent action of calcitonin involves Epac1 (17Larouche-Joubert N. Marsy S. Michelet S. Imbert-Teboul M. Doucet A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 18598-18604Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar), a Rap-specific guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) directly activated by cAMP, independent of PKA (18de Rooij J. Zwartkruis F.J.T. Verheijen M.H.G. Cool R.H. Nijman S.M.B. Wittinghofer A. Bos J.L. Nature. 1998; 396: 474-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (1634) Google Scholar, 19Kawasaki H. Springett G.M. Mochizuki N. Toki S. Nakaya M. Matsuda M. Housman D.E. Graybiel A.M. Science. 1998; 282: 2275-2279Crossref PubMed Scopus (1179) Google Scholar, 20Bos J.L. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2003; 4: 733-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (416) Google Scholar). Very recently, an involvement of Epac in ERK activation by 5-HT7 receptors in cultured rat hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells and by the parathyroid hormone-related protein in osteoblasts has been reported as well (21Lin S.L. Johnson-Farley N.N. Lubinsky D.R. Cowen D.S. J. Neurochem. 2003; 87: 1076-1085Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 22Chen C. Koh A.J. Datta N.S. Zhang J. Keller E.T. Xiao G. Franceschi R.T. D′Silva N.J. McCauley L.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 29121-29129Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). On the other hand, in human melanocytes and B16 mouse melanoma cells, PKA-independent ERK activation by cAMP-elevating agents was shown to be mediated by Ras, but not Rap1 (23Buscà R. Abbe P. Mantoux F. Aberdam E. Peyssonnaux C. Eychène A. Ortonne J.-P. Ballotti R. EMBO J. 2000; 19: 2900-2910Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar). Thus, Rap1 and Ras are obviously key regulators of ERK activation by Gs-coupled receptors. Activation of these small GTPases, i.e. GTP loading, is catalyzed by several distinct GEFs, comprising about 20 distinct proteins (24Zwartkruis F.J.T. Bos J.L. Exp. Cell Res. 1999; 253: 157-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 25Erhardt A. Erhardt G.R.A. Guo X. Schrader J.W. Exp. Hematol. 2002; 30: 1089-1106Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar, 26Quilliam L.A. Rebhuhn J.F. Castro A.F. Prog. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002; 71: 391-444Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Some of these GEFs exhibit Rap specificity, as the above mentioned Epacs and the PDZ-GEFs, whereas others are Ras-specific, such as the SOS and GRF family members. In addition, some of these GEFs, e.g. members of the RasGRP/CalDAG-GEFs, have been reported to activate both Rap and Ras GTPases (24Zwartkruis F.J.T. Bos J.L. Exp. Cell Res. 1999; 253: 157-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 25Erhardt A. Erhardt G.R.A. Guo X. Schrader J.W. Exp. Hematol. 2002; 30: 1089-1106Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar, 26Quilliam L.A. Rebhuhn J.F. Castro A.F. Prog. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002; 71: 391-444Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The latter group of GEFs also includes the recently identified phospholipase C-ϵ (PLC-ϵ), which via its CDC25 domain can activate Rap1A and Ras and induce Ras-dependent ERK activation (27Song C. Hu C.-D. Masago M. Kariya K.-i. Yamawaki-Kataoka Y. Shibatohge M. Wu D. Satoh T. Kataoka T. J. Biol. Oncogene. 2002; 21: 8105-8113Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). Interestingly, this PLC isoform can also be activated by Ras and Rap GTPases, apparently by binding to a separate domain, the RA2 domain (27Song C. Hu C.-D. Masago M. Kariya K.-i. Yamawaki-Kataoka Y. Shibatohge M. Wu D. Satoh T. Kataoka T. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 2752-2757Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (281) Google Scholar, 28Lopez I. Mak E.C. Ding J. Hamm H.E. Lomasney J.W. J. Oncogene. 2002; 21: 8105-8113Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). We have recently shown that activation of two typical Gs-coupled receptors, the β2-AR transiently expressed in HEK-293 cells and a receptor for prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) endogenously expressed in N1E-115 neuroblastoma cells, leads to stimulation of PLC-ϵ and increases [Ca2+]i in a cAMP-dependent manner (31Schmidt M. Evellin S. Oude Weernink P.A. vom Dorp F. Rehmann H. Lomasney J.W. Jakobs K.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 1020-1024Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar). These Gs-coupled receptor actions were independent of PKA but mediated by cAMP-activated Epac1 and subsequent activation of the GTPase, Rap2B (31Schmidt M. Evellin S. Oude Weernink P.A. vom Dorp F. Rehmann H. Lomasney J.W. Jakobs K.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 1020-1024Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar). The aim of the present study was to analyze whether these Gs-coupled receptors use this pathway, particularly Epac1 and PLC-ϵ, for ERK activation. We report here that ERK activation by the β2-AR and the PGE1 receptor in HEK-293 cells and N1E-115 neuroblastoma cells, respectively, is mediated by cAMP-activated Epac proteins, which then lead via Rap2B and PLC-ϵ stimulation to [Ca2+]i increase, finally resulting in activation of H-Ras as a trigger of the MAP kinase cascade. Materials, Expression Plasmids, and Transfection—Forskolin, PGE1, 2′,5′-dideoxyadenosine, BAPTA/AM, calmidazolium, fluphenazine, Gö 6976, H-89, PD98059, PP2, U0126, and W7 were from Calbiochem-Merck Biosciences and adrenaline and propranolol from Sigma. PTX was from Biomol, and 8-(4-chlorophenylthio)-2′-O-methyl cyclic AMP (8-pCPT-2Me-cAMP) was from BIOLOGLife Science Institute (Bremen, Germany). The anti-Epac1, anti-Epac2, anti-ERK, anti-Rap2, and anti-H-Ras antibodies were from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. The anti-c-Myc and anti-HA antibodies were from Roche Applied Science. The antiphospho-ERK1/2 (P-ERK1/2) antibody was from New England Biolabs. The anti-PLC-ϵ antibody was kindly provided by Dr. J. W. Lomasney. cDNAs encoding wild-type PLC-ϵ, lipase-inactive H1144L PLC-ϵ, β2-AR, K298M c-Src, and the carboxyl terminus of β-adrenergic receptor kinase (β-ARK-CT) were kindly provided by Drs. J. W. Lomasney, R. Jockers, J. T. Parsons, and R. J. Lefkowitz. cDNAs encoding the mutants of the Ras-like GTPases were kindly provided by Drs. J. L. Bos and J. de Gunzburg. cDNAs encoding HA-tagged Epac1, Rap GTPase-activating proteinII (RapGAPII), RasGRP1, RasGRP2, and RasGRP3 were kindly provided by Drs. J. L. Bos, H. Rehmann and J. de Rooij. HEK-293 cells and N1E-115 neuroblastoma cells grown to near confluence on 145-mm culture dishes were transfected with an efficiency of at least 50% as reported before (31Schmidt M. Evellin S. Oude Weernink P.A. vom Dorp F. Rehmann H. Lomasney J.W. Jakobs K.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 1020-1024Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar, 32Voss M. Oude Weernink P.A. Haupenthal S. Möller U. Cool R.H. Bauer B. Camonis J.H. Jakobs K.H. Schmidt M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 34691-34698Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar) with the following amounts of plasmid DNA: 25 μg each of DNA of β2-AR, Epac1, wild-type PLC-ϵ, ΔCDC25 PLC-ϵ, G12V Rap2B, and RasGRP1–3, 50 μg each of DNA of wild-type H-Ras and Rap2B, 75 μg of DNA of K298M c-Src, and 100 μg each of β-ARK-CT, R279K Epac1, RapGAPII, S17N H-Ras, S17N Rap2B, and H1144L PLC-ϵ. Expression of the encoded proteins was verified by immunoblotting of cell lysates with specific antibodies. Assays were performed 48 h after transfection. For PTX treatment, the cells were incubated for 16 h with 100 ng/ml PTX. Construction of R279K Epac1 and ΔCDC25 PLC-ϵ—The Epac1 mutant, R279K Epac1, with a point mutation in the cAMP-binding pocket (19Kawasaki H. Springett G.M. Mochizuki N. Toki S. Nakaya M. Matsuda M. Housman D.E. Graybiel A.M. Science. 1998; 282: 2275-2279Crossref PubMed Scopus (1179) Google Scholar) was generated with a QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene). PCR was carried out with 50 ng of the plasmid carrying the Epac1 cDNA (GenBank™ accession number AF103905) and complementary primers containing the desired mutation (mismatching nucleotides are in bold; forward: 5′-ggtgaatgatgcacccaaggcagccaccatcatcc-3′; reverse: 5′-ggatgatggtggctgccttgggtgcatcattcacc-3′). Subsequently, the methylated parental DNA was digested with DpnI endonuclease, and the nicked vector with the desired mutation was transformed into Escherichia coli. The PLC-ϵ deletion mutant ΔCDC25 PLC-ϵ was constructed by replacing the KpnI/StuI fragment of wild-type PLC-ϵ cDNA by a corresponding PCR product of this region lacking the complete sequence of the CDC25 domain (amino acids 220–523). PCR was performed with a primer pair flanking the 5′-terminus of cDNA encoding PLC-ϵ inclusive of the KpnI/StuI fragment (forward, 5′-taatacgactcactataggg-3′; reverse, 5′-ttctcgaggccttctgtgagtcctctgaaggctgcagatcgatcagctccttg-3′) and PLC-ϵ subcloned in pcDNA3 as template using the Expand High Fidelity PCR system (Roche Applied Science). Thereafter, the PCR fragment was ligated into the vector pGEM-T Easy by TA cloning (Promega). As PLC-ϵ contains a second StuI restriction site beyond the open reading frame, the NdeI/XbaI fragment of PLC-ϵ was subcloned into pET-23a (Novagen) to receive the pET-23a-PLC-ϵ plasmid. This construct was digested with KpnI/StuI and ligated with the appropriately cut PCR product, resulting in the full-length cDNA of ΔCDC25 PLC-ϵ. Finally, the NdeI/XbaI fragment of pET-23a-ΔCDC25 PLC-ϵ was cloned into pcDNA3 to obtain ΔCDC25 PLC-ϵ. The correct sequences were verified by sequencing. ERK Activation Assay—For measurement of ERK activation, HEK-293 cells and N1E-115 neuroblastoma cells were serum starved for 16 h and then incubated for the indicated periods of time at 37 °C with the indicated agents, followed by cell lysis in a buffer containing 1% SDS and 10 mm Tris/HCl, pH 7.4 and five passages through a 25-gauge needle (32Voss M. Oude Weernink P.A. Haupenthal S. Möller U. Cool R.H. Bauer B. Camonis J.H. Jakobs K.H. Schmidt M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 34691-34698Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). Thereafter, the lysates were clarified by centrifugation, followed by determination of protein concentration and incubation in Laemmli buffer for 10 min at 95 °C. After SDS-PAGE and transfer to nitrocellulose membranes, phosphorylated ERK1 and ERK2 were detected with the anti-P-ERK1/2 antibody. Densitometric analysis of the bands (P-ERK1 plus P-ERK2) was performed with ImageQuant software (Amersham Biosciences). Activation of H-Ras and Rap2B—Serum-starved HEK-293 cells and N1E-115 neuroblastoma cells transfected with wild-type H-Ras or Rap2B were stimulated for 5 min at 37 °C with the indicated agents. After cell lysis, activated H-Ras and Rap2B were extracted with glutathione S-transferase (GST)-tagged Raf1-RBD (Ras-binding domain of Raf-1) and GST-tagged RalGDS-RBD (Rap-binding domain of the Ral guanine nucleotide dissociation stimulator), respectively, each bound to glutathione-Sepharose beads, and immunoblotting with anti-H-Ras or anti-Rap2 antibodies as described before (31Schmidt M. Evellin S. Oude Weernink P.A. vom Dorp F. Rehmann H. Lomasney J.W. Jakobs K.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 1020-1024Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar, 33de Rooij J. Bos J.L. Oncogene. 1997; 14: 623-625Crossref PubMed Scopus (420) Google Scholar, 34Wolthuis R.M. de Ruiter N.D. Cool R.H. Bos J.L. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6748-6761Crossref PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar). Densitometric analysis of the bands was performed with ImageQuant software (Amersham Biosciences). Immunoblot Analysis—For detection of P-ERK1/2, Epac1, Epac2 (dilution of 1:1000), c-Myc (dilution of 1:200), HA, ERK1/2, Rap2B, and H-Ras (each at a dilution of 1:500), equal (or indicated) amounts of protein were separated by SDS-PAGE on 10% acrylamide gels. After transfer to nitrocellulose membranes and a 1-h incubation with the antibodies at the dilution factors given above, the proteins were visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence. Data Presentation—Data shown in the figures are mean ± S.E. of n independent experiments, each performed in triplicate. Comparisons between means were either with the Student's paired t test or one-way analysis of variance test. A difference was regarded as significant at p < 0.05. Characterization of ERK Activation by the β2-AR in HEK-293 Cells—We have recently reported that the β2-AR transiently expressed in HEK-293 cells mediates PLC-ϵ stimulation and [Ca2+]i increase by a pathway involving the cAMP-regulated Rap-GEF Epac1 and the GTPase Rap2B (31Schmidt M. Evellin S. Oude Weernink P.A. vom Dorp F. Rehmann H. Lomasney J.W. Jakobs K.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 1020-1024Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar). Here we studied whether this signaling pathway contributes to activation of MAP kinases, specifically ERK1 and ERK2, by the β2-AR. As reported before (31Schmidt M. Evellin S. Oude Weernink P.A. vom Dorp F. Rehmann H. Lomasney J.W. Jakobs K.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 1020-1024Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar), the HEK-293 cells used for the present study do not endogenously express β2-ARs; accordingly, treatment of untransfected cells with the β2-AR agonist, adrenaline, did not induce MAP kinase activation (data not shown). However, upon expression of the β2-AR, agonist activation of the receptor induced a strong, but transient, phosphorylation of ERK1 and ERK2. The stimulatory effect of adrenaline reached its maximum at 2–5 min and rather rapidly disappeared thereafter (Fig. 1A). Half-maximal and maximal activation was observed at about 1 and 10 μm adrenaline, respectively (Fig. 1B). Phosphorylation of ERK1/2 induced by adrenaline (10 μm) was fully blocked by the β2-AR antagonist propranolol (1 μm) (see Fig. 3B), as well as by the MAP kinase kinase inhibitors PD98059 (10 μm) and U0126 (10 μm) (data not shown).Fig. 3Role of c-Src, Gi proteins, Gβγ, Rap1A, and H-Ras for ERK activation by the β -AR. HEK-293 cells transfected with the β2-AR alone (Ctr) or together with K298M c-Src (A), β2-ARK-CT (B), S17N Rap1A or S17N H-Ras (C) were incubated for 5 min without (–) and with (+) 10 μm adrenaline in the absence and presence of 1 μm propranolol (B, Prop). Where indicated, cells were treated for 15 min and 16 h before agonist stimulation with 10 μm PP2 (A) and 100 ng/ml PTX (B), respectively. Representative immunoblots of P-ERK1/2 and ERK1/2 are presented (n = 3–5). The insets show the immunoblot detection of c-Src, Rap1A, and H-Ras.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Previous studies on activation of ERK1/2 by the β2-AR in HEK-293 cells indicated that this Gs-coupled receptor action involves cAMP, cAMP-activated PKA, the cytosolic tyrosine kinase c-Src, eventually Gi proteins and Gβγ dimers, and either Rap1A or H-Ras as final activators of the MAP kinase cascade (8Daaka Y. Luttrell L.M. Lefkowitz R.J. Nature. 1997; 390: 88-91Crossref PubMed Scopus (1077) Google Scholar, 10Schmitt J.M. Stork P.J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25342-25350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar, 11Friedmann J. Babu B. Clark R.B. Mol. Pharmacol. 2002; 62: 1094-1102Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar, 12Schmitt J.M. Stork P.J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 43024-43032Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Similar to these studies, we observed that ERK activation by the β2-AR was mimicked by direct activation of adenylyl cyclase with forskolin, although its action was less rapid and more sustained than that of the receptor agonist, adrenaline (Fig. 2A). Maximal ERK1/2 phosphorylation induced by forskolin (30 μm) was observed at 15–30 min and slowly declined thereafter. Furthermore, the direct adenylyl cyclase inhibitor 2′,5′-dideoxyadenosine (10 μm) suppressed the stimulatory effects of both adrenaline (n = 4; p <0.001) and forskolin (not shown) on phosphorylation of ERK1/2 (Fig. 2B). However, treatment of the cells with the PKA inhibitor H-89 (10 μm) did not alter ERK activation induced by the β2-AR or forskolin (not shown) at any time point measured (Fig. 2B), indicating that the β2-AR-induced ERK activation is cAMP-dependent, but independent of PKA. To test for a possible involvement of c-Src, the cells were treated with the c-Src inhibitor PP2 (10 μm) or transfected with the kinase-deficient c-Src mutant K298M c-Src, which both interfered with epidermal growth factor signaling in these cells (35Stope M.B. vom Dorp F. Szatkowski D. Böhm A. Keiper M. Nolte J. Oude Weernink P.A. Rosskopf D. Evellin S. Jakobs K.H. Schmidt M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2004; 24: 4664-4676Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). Neither of these treatments suppressed adrenaline-induced ERK1/2 phosphorylation (Fig. 3A), although it was noted that PP2 reduced both basal and adrenaline-induced phosphorylation of ERK1/2 by some 30% (n = 4; p < 0.03). Treatment of the HEK-293 cells with PTX (16 h, 100 ng/ml), to interfere with potential coupling of the β2-AR to Gi proteins, did not alter phosphorylation of ERK1/2 by adrenaline either (Fig. 3B). Furthermore, scavenging of Gβγ dimers by expression of β-ARK-CT (36Koch W.J. Hawes B. Inglese J. Luttrell L.M. Lefkowitz R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6193-6197Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) did not affect ERK activation by the β2-AR (Fig. 3B). These treatments fully (PTX) or at least partially (β-ARK-CT) blocked ERK activation by Gi-coupled sphingosine 1-phosphate receptors endogenously expressed in these cells (data not shown). Finally, we asked which type of small GTPase acts as final effector of the β2-AR signaling cascade leading to activation of the MAP kinases. As illustrated in Fig. 3C, phosphorylation of ERK1/2 induced by adrenaline was strongly reduced by expression of dominant negative S17N H-Ras (n = 5; p < 0.008), but not altered by expression of S17N Rap1A. Similar data were obtained when the effects of S17N H-Ras and S17N Rap1A were examined on ERK1/2 phosphorylation induced by forskolin (data not shown). Thus, ERK activation by the β2-AR expressed in HEK-293 cells apparently required cAMP and H-Ras, but not PKA, Gi proteins, c-Src, and Rap1A. Heparan sulfate structure differs significantly between various cell types and during different developmental stages. The diversity is created during biosynthesis by sulfotransferases, which add sulfate groups to the growing chain, and a C5-epimerase, which converts selected glucuronic acid residues to iduronic acid. All these modifications are believed to depend on initial glucosamine N-sulfation carried out by the enzyme glucosaminyl N-deacetylase/N-sulfotransferase (NDST). Here we report that heparan sulfate synthesized by mouse embryonic stem cells deficient in NDST1 and NDST2 completely lacks N-sulfation but still contains 6-O-sulfate groups, demonstrating that 6-O-sulfation can occur without prior N-sulfation. Reverse transcriptase-PCR analysis indicates that all three identified 6-O-sulfotransferases are expressed by the cells, 6-O-sulfotransferase-1 being the dominating form. The 6-O-sulfated polysaccharide lacking N-sulfate groups also contains N-unsubstituted glucosamine units, raising questions about how these units are generated. The diversity is created during biosynthesis by sulfotransferases, which add sulfate groups to the growing chain, and a C5-epimerase, which converts selected glucuronic acid residues to iduronic acid. All these modifications are believed to depend on initial glucosamine N-sulfation carried out by the enzyme glucosaminyl N-deacetylase/N-sulfotransferase (NDST). Here we report that heparan sulfate synthesized by mouse embryonic stem cells deficient in NDST1 and NDST2 completely lacks N-sulfation but still contains 6-O-sulfate groups, demonstrating that 6-O-sulfation can occur without prior N-sulfation. Reverse transcriptase-PCR analysis indicates that all three identified 6-O-sulfotransferases are expressed by the cells, 6-O-sulfotransferase-1 being the dominating form. The 6-O-sulfated polysaccharide lacking N-sulfate groups also contains N-unsubstituted glucosamine units, raising questions about how these units are generated.
